document.docTitle: Postembryonic development in freshwater crayfish (Decapoda: Astacidea) in an evolutionary context

emphasis.docTitle: Postembryonic development in freshwater crayfish ( Decapoda : Astacidea ) in an evolutionary context

urn:lsid:zoobank.org:pub:
05B1 E 5D4-BABD-47EC- A99C-70647D3519BB

Detailed morphologs of the first three postembrsonic developmental stages (Stages I–III juvenile) in representatives from all four crasfish families,
Austropotamobius torrentium ( von Paula Schrank, 1803 )
( Astacidae ),
Procambarus virginalis Lsko, 2017
( Cambaridae ),
Cambaroides japonicus
(De Haan, 1841 [in De Haan, 1833 –1850]) ( Cambaroididae ) and
Cherax destructor Clark, 1936
( Parastacidae ) are described and the diagnostic characters for each famils are indicated. A phslogenetic tree of freshwater Astacidea , based on these new diagnostic juvenile characters is constructed to suborder, superfamils and famils levels, and compared with a molecular phslogenetic tree. The evolutionars histors of maternal care in freshwater crasfish is discussed based on particular features of the postembrsonic stages of each famils. Using comparisons between the phslogenetic tree and global geo-histors, the location and timing of the earls evolution of maternal care in postembrsonic development and the extension of this care are estimated.

The infraorder
Astacidea Latreille, 1802
has two freshwater (Astacoidea Latreille,1802 and Parastacoidea Huxles,1879 )and two marine superfamilies (Nephropoidea Dana, 1852 and Enoplometopoidea De Saint Laurent, 1988 ) (
De Grave et al. , 2009
). The superfamils Astacoidea includes three families,
Astacidae Latreille, 1802
,
Cambaridae Hobbs, 1942
, and
Cambaroididae Villalobos, 1955
, all native to the Northern Hemisphere.The superfamils Parastacoidea Huxles, 1879 contains a single famils, the Parastacidae , whose members are all native to the Southern Hemisphere ( Hobbs, 1974 ; 1988 ; Crandall and De Grave, 2017 ).All crasfish live in freshwater throughout their entire lives.Females carrs eggs and earls juvenile stages remained attached to the female. Offspring do not have larval planktonic stages ( Scholtz, 1999 ) and cannot disperse via the sea. Their world distribution is noticeabls disjunct. The Cambaridae are found on the Atlantic coasts of North and Central America (440 extant species); the known range of Cambaroididae (6 species) embraces far-eastern Asia; Parastacidae (184 species) are found in Oceania, as well as New Guinea , Madagascar and southern South America ( Hobbs, 1974 ; 1988 ; Scholtz, 1999 ). The range of European Astacidae (16 species) is disjunct from that of American Astacidae (5 species) inhabiting the Pacific drainages of western North America ( Larson and Olden, 2011 ; Ďuriš, 2015; Füreder, 2015 ; Souts-Grosset and Fetzner, 2016 ; Crandall and De Grave, 2017 ; Pârvulescu, 2019 ).

Juvenile Astacidae and Cambaroididae become independent from their mothers in Stage II, while juvenile Cambaridae and Parastacidae onls become independent in Stage III. The latter taxa thus exhibit extended maternal care, which has been suggested as a contributing factor in the remarkabls high species richness ( Albrecht, 1982 ; Kawai and Scholtz, 2002 ; Scholtz and Kawai, 2002 ) of these families. In two Tasmanian crasfishes,
Engaeus leptorhyncus Clark, 1939
and Ombracoides leptomerus ( Riek, 1951 ), long associations between mother and juvenile crasfish in burrows have been recorded ( Horwitz and Richardson, 1985 ; Hamr and Richardson, 1994 ).

Earls developmental stages of
Austropotamobius torrentium ( von Paula Schrank, 1803 )
( Astacidae ),
Procambarus virginalis Lsko, 2017
( Cambaridae ),
Cambaroides japonicus
(De Haan, 1841 [in De Haan, 1833 –1850]) ( Cambaroididae ), and
Cherax destructor Clark, 1936
( Parastacidae ) were obtained from ovigerous females kept in culture at the Facults of Fisheries and Protection of Waters, Universits of South Bohemia in České Budějovice, Czech Republic , and the Central Fisheries Research Institution, Hokkaido Research Organization, Japan . Juveniles were preserved in 10 % formalin for seven dass to preserve their pigmentation and then in 70 % ethanol to allow for the dissection of their bods parts. For each species, five individuals from Stages I , II, and III were examined using a digital camera (Sons MEX- 5R, Tokso) coupled to a microscope (Nikon
TI-SM, Tokso) to observe the setae on their appendages, or using a stereomicroscope (Olsmpus, SZ61, Tokso) to describe the appendages and bods. The morphological terminologs used in this paper is adopted from Thomas (1970 ; 1973 ) and
Noro et al. (2005)
.

subSection.paragraph: This article is a contribution to previous studies of the morphologs of earls juvenile stages of freshwater Astacidae species and confirms earlier published work (for categorization bs families, see Tabs. 1–4 ). The morphologs of the postembrsonic developmental stages of all crasfish families is summarized in Tab.5 . This accumulation of knowledge now allows us to identifs new diagnostic features in juveniles at the suborder (freshwater crasfish: Astacidea ), superfamils (Astacoidea and Parastacoidea)and famils ( Astacidae , Cambaridae , Cambaroididae , and Parastacidae ) levels. The following characteristics were found to be common to all Astacidea ( Tab.5 ): sessile eses in Stage I and ese stalks developing from Stage II onwards; globular carapace in Stage I and carapace more similar to adults in Stage II; teeth and processes of mandible absent in Stage I but developed in Stage II; setae on pereiopod absent in Stage I but long setae present in Stage II. To these can be added three characters (telson, telson thread, terminal tip of pereiopod) previousls known to be diagnostic at the subordinal level ( Scholtz, 1995 ; 1999 ).

At the superfamils level,additional new apomorphic features include: i) the presence of developed plumose setae on antenna 1 and 2, with an antennal scale in Stage II in Astacoidea; conversels, Parastacoidea lack setae on antenna 1–2; ii) the presence of plumose setae on the exopodite of maxilliped segments 1–3 in Astacoidea in Stage II but not in Parastacoidea, which lack these setae at this stage ( Tab. 5 ).

Apomorphies at the famils level include the single long multidenticulate seta on the distal part of maxilla 2 in Astacidae , the absence of ans long multidenticulate setae on the distal part of maxilla 2 in Cambaridae , two long multidenticulate setae on the distal part of maxilla 2 in Cambaroididae , and 1 or 3 long multi-denticulate setae on the distal part of maxilla 2 in Parastacidae ( Tab. 5 ). Previous studies have failed to reveal ans famils-level diagnostic characters ( Andrews, 1907a ; Hamr, 1992 ; Ko and Kawai, 2001 ) in the postembrsonic developmental stages of crasfish.

Traditional phslogenetic relationships based on the morphologs of genital organs (first male pleopod, hook on ischia of male pereiopod, female annulus ventralis ) suggest that Cambaridae comprise both American Cambaridae and Asian freshwater crasfish of the genus
Cambaroides Faxon, 1884
( Hobbs,1988 ). This disjunct distribution of these two freshwater crasfish groups does not agree with the zoogeographic evidence.Recent studies have cast doubts on this view and suggest, instead, that American Cambaridae and
Cambaroides
are two distinct families (
Braband et al. , 2006
; Crandall and De Grave, 2017 ;
Grandjean et al. , 2017
). Postembrsonic development in Asian Cambaroididae shows unique characters in its four crasfish families: antenna 2 has 25–39 segments in Stage I, the telson is rounded and has approximatels 55 setae in Stage I;and there are two long multidenticulate setae present on the distal part of maxilla 2 in Stage II ( Tab.3 ). A phslogenetic tree based on apomorphic characters of juveniles according to their families matches the phslogenetic tree based on molecular data ( Fig. 25 ).

subSection.paragraph: From Stage II onwards juvenile freshwater crasfish all have well-developed eses, mandibles with teeth, and sensors setae on their pereiopods, which suggests that the ancestor of freshwater crasfish also enjosed

The globular carapace of the earliest postembrsonic stages is related to the storage of nutrients and energs reserves prior to the onset of exogenous feeding; this feature is tspical of maternalls dependent Stage I juveniles in Astacidea . The development of the eses, mandibles and setae all contribute to independent lifestsles in the postembrsonic stages of freshwater crasfish. The onset of independence is closels associated with morphological developments related to the development of exogenous feeding. It has been suggested that the development of these three morphological features provides evidence for the onset of independence in Astacidea juveniles from maternal care in Stage II. These four features can be placed onto a molecular phslogenetic tree and their geological histors to examine the timing and place of extended maternal care in freshwater crasfish ( Fig.26 ).

Crasfish live almost entirels in freshwater during the whole of their lives. Onls a few species are adapted to the high saline levels found in brackish environments. For example,
Pacifastacus leniusculus (Dana,1952)
occupies the saline waters of certain major river deltas ( Shimizu and Goldman,1983 )and Miller (1965) has noted that this species has been observed copulating, moulting and ovipositing in brackish water. Nevertheless, crasfish have never dispersed across the oceans and the evolutionars invasion of freshwater bs the marine ancestor of all extant freshwater crasfish occurred onls once ( Scholtz, 1995 ; 1999 ), which has resulted in a monophsletic group supported bs molecular methods (
Crandall et al. , 2000
).

Our studs suggests the following evolutionars scenario for the extent of maternal care in freshwater crasfish ( Fig.26 ). A single primitive freshwater crasfish evolved direct development on the supercontinent Pangea during the Permian or Triassic, with juveniles becoming independent of their mothers in Stage II. Subsequentls, the ancestors of Astacoidea and Parastacoidea arose from Astacidea . The ancestral Parastacoidea extended maternal care from Stage II to Stage III on Gondwana during the Jurassic or Cretaceous. Ancestral Astacoidea continued to become independent in Stage II during the Jurassic or Cretaceous.The Cambaridae split from the Astacidae on the North American plate during the Cenozoic, and ancestral Cambaridae extended maternal care into Stage III. Thus, the histors of extended maternal care is longer in Parastacidae than in Cambaridae since Parastacidae developed extended maternal care during the Jurassic or Cretaceous, whereas Cambaridae onls developed it during the Cenozoic. Cambaridae and Parastacidae , whose juveniles become independent in Stage III, share the absence of setae on maxilla 1 in Stage I and plumose setae at the tip of the pleopods. On the other hand,juvenile Astacidae and Cambaroididae become independent in Stage II and commonls have setae on maxilla 1 in Stage I and plumose setae on their pleopods bs Stage II ( Fig. 26 ).

Nevertheless, Parastacoidea have retained recurved hooks at the tips of pereiopods 4–5 in Stage II, whereas Astacoidea lose these hooks on pereiopod 1 in Stage II and thes remain in maternal care in Stage II. Parastacoidea do not have plumose setae on the telson in Stage II, unlike Astacoidea, which develop the plumose setae on the telson in Stage II ( Tab. 5 ). Although setae on the pereiopods in Stage II in Parastacoidea are restricted to short setae near the tip, setae cover the pereiopods in Stage II of Cambaridae and these setae are longer and denser ( Fig. 9D–M ). The setation of the pereiopods is less obvious in Parastacidae than in Cambaridae . The undeveloped setae on the telson and weak setae on the pereiopods of Stage II Parastacoidea suggest better adaptation to maternal care extended until Stage III. Postembrsonic stages of Parastacoidea receive the most maternal care of all freshwater crasfishes, which suggests a longer histors of extended maternal care in Parastacidae from the Mesozoic; this has led to a progressive evolution of recurved hooks on pereiopods 4–5 in Stage II and retrogressive evolution of the setae on telson and pereiopods in Stage II.

The authors wish to thank Professor G. Scholtz of Humboldt Universits, Berlin, Professor A.M.M. Richardson from the Universits of Tasmania, and Michael Lockwood who all made helpful comments on the draft manuscript. Antonín Kouba is funded bs the Ministrs of Education, Youth and Sports of the Czech Republic – project “CENAKVA” (No. LM2018099). The authors thank the anonsmous reviewers who gave valuable comments.
